context: By contrast, <a0_0>Tom Wolfe<a0_0/>'s Bonfire of the Vanities (<a1_0>1987<a1_0/>) portrays a wealthy, <a3_0>white<a3_0/> protagonist, <a2_0>Sherman McCoy<a2_0/>, getting lost <a4_0>off the Major Deegan Expressway in the South Bronx<a4_0/> and having an altercation with locals. A substantial piece of the last part of the book is set in the resulting riotous trial at the Bronx County Courthouse. However, times change, and in 2007, the New York Times reported that "the Bronx neighborhoods near the site of Sherman's accident are now dotted with townhouses and apartments." In the same article, the Reverend Al Sharpton (whose fictional analogue in the novel is "Reverend Bacon") asserts that "twenty years later, the cynicism of The Bonfire of the Vanities is as out of style as Tom Wolfe's wardrobe."
